intro: Ceriops pseudodecandra, commonly known as the mangrove apple or sea apple, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Rhizophoraceae and is characterized by its ability to thrive in saline and waterlogged soils. The plant has prop roots that help anchor it in tidal zones and facilitate oxygen uptake. Its small, white flowers are borne in clusters, and it produces edible, fleshy berries that are a food source for various wildlife. This species plays an important ecological role in stabilizing coastal ecosystems and supporting biodiversity.
